sen.j: 政所（まんどころ）は、親王、三位以上の公卿に設置を許された家政機関のこと。
sen.e: Mandokoro (政所) is an administrative board for domestic economy, which Imperial princes/princesses and court nobles ranked Sanmi (The Third Rank) or higher were allowed to set up.
sen.cmt: 一文にするため、「親王、三位以上の公卿に設置を許された家政機関のこと。」を下のセルから移動させ文末に追加しました家政機関→administrative board for domestic economy 親王→Imperial princes/princesses 三位以上の公卿→court nobles ranked Sanmi (The Third Rank) or higher
sen.e: Mandokoro （政所） was an administrative board for domestic economy that was allowed to be set up by Imperial princes, princesses and court nobles ranked Sanmi (Third Rank) or higher.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: Mandokoro was an administrative board for domestic economy that was allowed to be set up by Imperial princes, princesses and court nobles ranked Sanmi (Third Rank) or higher.

sen.j: 平安時代に設けられた。
sen.e: It was set up in the Heian Period
Mandokoro was opened in the Heian Period.
Mandokoro was opened in the Heian period.

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府の職制の一。
sen.e: It is one component of the office organization system in Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
sen.cmt: 鎌倉幕府→Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun),
sen.e: It was one component of the office organization system within the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
It was one component of the office organization system within the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: 室町幕府の職制の一。
sen.e: It is one component of the office organization system in Muromachi bakufu.
It was one component of the office organization system within the Muromachi bakufu as well.
It was one component of the office organization system within the Muromachi bakufu as well.

sen.j: 政所茶は滋賀県東近江市永源寺地区にある茶畑から収穫される茶。
sen.e: Mandokorocha is a kind of tea leaves gathered in the tea plantation at Eigenji area in Higashiomi City, Shiga Prefecture.
sen.cmt: 政所茶→Mandokorocha 茶畑→tea gardens (plantation) 滋賀県東近江市永源寺地区→Eigenji area in Higashiomi City, Shiga Prefecture.
sen.e: Mandokorocha is a kind of tea leaf that is gathered at the tea plantation in the Eigenji area of Higashiomi City, Shiga Prefecture.
Mandokorocha is a kind of tea leaf that is gathered at the tea plantation in the Eigenji area of Higashiomi City, Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 「宇治は茶所、茶は政所」という歌があるほど有名。
sen.e: It is so famous that there is a song that sings as, 'Uji is the center of production and tea is the production of Mandokoro."
sen.cmt: 「宇治は茶所、茶は政所」→ 'Uji is the center of production and tea is the production of Mandokoro"としました。
sen.e: The tea is so famous that there is a song written about it that sings, "Uji is the center of production and tea is the production of Mandokoro."
sen.cmt: It→The tea; fixed grammar to sound more natural
sen.e: The tea is so famous that there is a song written about it that sings, 'Uji is the center of production and tea is the production of Mandokoro.'

tit.e: Mandokoro of Imperial families and court nobles
Mandokoro of the Imperial family and court nobles
Mandokoro of the Imperial Family and court nobles

sen.j: 親王、従三位以上の公家の家政を担当する機関。
sen.e: It is an administrative board for domestic economy of the Imperial families and the court nobles ranked Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) or higher.
sen.cmt: 従三位以上の公家→court nobles ranked Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) or higher
sen.e: Mandokoro is an administrative board in charge of the domestic economy of Japan run by the Imperial family and court nobles ranked Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) or higher.
Mandokoro is an administrative board in charge of the domestic economy of Japan run by the Imperial Family and court nobles ranked Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) or higher.

sen.j: 事務官を家司という。
sen.e: The officers of the board is called Keishi (household superintendent）.
sen.cmt: 家司→Keishi (household superintendent）[The Cambridge History of Japan]
sen.e: Officers of the board were called Keishi (household superintendent).
Officers of the board were called Keishi (household superintendent).

sen.j: 摂政・関白の夫人を北政所と称するのも、夫人が家庭内の家政を統括していた事に由来している（その住まいは邸宅の北側に設置される事が多かった）。
sen.e: The reason why the wife of sessho (regent)/kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) was called Kita no Mandokoro derives from the fact that the wife took the initiative of domestic economy of the family (and her living quarter was often located in the north side of the residence.
sen.cmt: 摂政→sessho (regent) 関白→kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) 北政所→Kita no Mandokoro
sen.e: The reason why the wife of a sessho (regent) and kanpaku (chief advisor to the Emperor) were called Kita no Mandokoro (the north Mandokoro) derives from the fact that the wife took initiative in matters of domestic economy in her family (This was also due to the wive's living quarters often being located on the north side of the residence.

The reason why the wife of a sessho (regent) and kanpaku (chief advisor to the Emperor) were called Kita no Mandokoro (the north Mandokoro) derives from the fact that the wife took initiative in matters of domestic economy in her family (This was also due to the wives' living quarters often being located on the north side of the residence).

sen.j: （また平安時代の貴族は婿取婚が普通のため、その邸宅は夫人の実家から夫人へと相続されたものであった）。
sen.e: In addition, in the Heian Period, among the aristocracy, a style of marriage in which a man married into his wife's family was common, and therefore, the residence was handed down from her family to the wife.)
sen.cmt: 婿取婚→定訳不明：a style of marriage in which a man married into his wife's familyとしました。
sen.e: In addition, during the Heian Period it was common among the aristocracy to have marriages where a man married into his wife's family which meant the residence was handed down from the family to the wife).
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: (In addition, during the Heian period it was common among the aristocracy to have marriages where a man married into his wife's family which meant the residence was handed down from the family to the wife).

sen.j: 荘園制が確立すると、政所が本所の荘務を担当する機関として機能することになる。
sen.e: When the Shoen (private estate) system was established, Mandokoro played the role as an institute in charge of estate management affairs, however, in the late Middle Ages when Shoen had declined and the domestic economy of the court nobles had failed, the substantive function of Mandokoro was gradually lost.

With the establishment of the Shoen (private estate) system, the Mandokoro became the institute in charge of estate management affairs. In the Middle Ages when Shoen declined, however, the domestic economy run by the court nobles stagnated and the essence of the Mandokoro was gradually lost.
sen.cmt: I was unable to keep this one sentence; fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: With the establishment of the Shoen (private estate) system, the Mandokoro became the institute in charge of estate management affairs.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: しかし、荘園が衰退して公家家政が不振となった中世後期には実質は失われていった。
sen.e: In the Middle Ages when Shoen declined, however, the domestic economy run by the court nobles stagnated and the essence of the Mandokoro was gradually lost.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

tit.cmt: 「政所政治」説→定訳不明：'Mandokoro Politics' Theoryとしました。

sen.j: なお、一時期「政所政治」説という学説があり、これは戦前に黒板勝美らによって唱えられた説で摂関政治期には摂政・関白が国政の全般を掌握していた。
sen.e: During a time, there was a theory called 'Mandokoro Politics' theory advocated by Katsumi KUROITA and others, which argued that during the period of regency, the sessho (regent) and kanpaku (chief adviser to the Emperor) gripped the whole State politics, and kudashibumi (document issued by a superior or office) by Mandokoro and migosho (a document for informing people of the decision of Third Rank or upper people) functioned instead of the Emperor's senshi (imperial decree), and the politics was carried out at Mandokoro instead of Dajokan (Grand council of State), and the Imperial Court was only in charge of rituals and ceremonies.
sen.cmt: 黒板勝美→Katsumi KUROITA 摂関政治期→the period of regency 下文→kudashibumi (document issued by a superior or office) 御教書→migosho (a document for informing people of the decision of Third Rank or upper people) 太政官→Dajokan (Grand council of State)
sen.e: For a period of time, there was a theory on 'Mandokoro Politics' advocated by people like Katsumi KUROITA which argued that prior to World War II, during a period of regency, the sessho and kanpaku (the regent and the chief advisor to the Emperor) were in charge of all State politics. The theory claimed that a kudashibumi (a document issued by a superior or official) issued by the Mandokoro, or a migosho (a document intended to pass on information regarding decisions made by nobles of Third Rank or higher) functioned in place of the Emperor's senshi (imperial decree), politics were carried out at Mandokoro rather than the Daijokan (Grand council of State), and the Imperial Court was only in charge of rituals and ceremonies.
sen.cmt: instead→in place of; broke the sentence into two; fixed grammar
sen.e: For a period of time, there was a theory on 'Mandokoro Politics' advocated by people like Katsumi KUROITA which argued that prior to World War II, during a period of regency, the sessho and kanpaku (the regent and the chief advisor to the Emperor) were in charge of all State politics.
sen.cmt: 用語統一一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: また、政所の下文や御教書が天皇の宣旨に替わって機能して太政官に代わって政所で政務が行われ、朝廷は儀式のみを行ったという説があった。
sen.e: The theory claimed that a kudashibumi (a document issued by a superior or official) issued by the Mandokoro, or a migosho (a document intended to pass on information regarding decisions made by nobles of Third Rank or higher) functioned in place of the Emperor's senshi (imperial decree), politics were carried out at Mandokoro rather than the Daijokan (Grand council of State), and the Imperial Court was only in charge of rituals and ceremonies.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: だが、戦後に入ると土田直鎮らによる批判などがあり、現在では院政初期までは摂政・関白と天皇との間に力関係の差はあっても、両者の協議によって政治判断が行われており、摂政・関白が専断的に政務を取った時期は存在しなかったこと、国政に関する命令は摂関政治全盛期でも宣旨・太政官符による命令系統が機能しており、政所下文及び御教書はあくまで摂政・関白個人の私的あるいは宣旨・太政官符内部の問題に対してのみ有効な命令文書であったことが明らかとされており、この説は成り立たないと考えられている。
sen.e: However, after Word War II, based on the criticisms of Naoshige TSUCHIDA, et al., and other factors, it is considered nowadays that this theory does not hold true because of the following reasons: until the early period of Insei (rule by the retired Emperor) even there was differences in the strength of authority between Sessho/Kanpaku and the Emperor, the political decisions were made through the consultation of both sides, and there was no period in which sessho and/or kanpaku arbitrarily took the initiatives in political affaires; the orders related to the state politics was issued based on the chain of command through senshi and daijoukanpu (official documents issued by Daijokan, Grand Council of State), even during the golden days of regency, and it was revealed that kudashibumi and migosho issued by Mandokoro were the ordering documents just effective for private or internal problems of the sessho and kanpaku themselves.
sen.cmt: 土田直鎮→Naoshige TSUCHIDA 院政→Insei (rule by the retired Emperor) 太政官符→Daijoukanpu (official documents issued by Daijokan, Grand Council of State),
sen.e: However, after World War II, based on the criticisms by people like Naoshige TSUCHIDA, the theory is no longer held as true for the following reasons: Until the early Insei Period (the period ruled by the retired Emperor), even if there were differences in strength of authority between the Sessho/Kanpaku and the Emperor, political decisions were made though a consulation of both sides, and there was never a time in which the Sessho and/or Kanpaku arbitrarily took the initiative in political affairs; and orders that related to state politics were issued based on the chain of command through senshi and daijyoukanpu (official documents issued by the Daijokan and the Grand Council of State) even during the golden days of the regency, and it was revealed that kudashibumi and migosho documents issued by the Mandokoro were only effective for private or internal problems of the sessho and kanpaku themselves.

However, after World War II, based on the criticisms by people like Naoshige TSUCHIDA, the theory is no longer held as true for the following reasons: Until the early Insei period (the period ruled by the retired Emperor), even if there were differences in strength of authority between the Sessho/Kanpaku and the Emperor, political decisions were made through a consultation of both sides, and there was never a time in which the Sessho and/or Kanpaku arbitrarily took the initiative in political affairs; and orders that related to state politics were issued based on the chain of command through senshi and daijokanpu (official documents issued by the Daijokan and the Grand Council of State) even during the golden days of the regency, and it was revealed that kudashibumi and migosho documents issued by the Mandokoro were only effective for private or internal problems of the sessho and kanpaku themselves.

sen.j: 政所は鎌倉幕府の統治機構のひとつ。
sen.e: Mandokoro is a governing institution of Kamakura bakufu.
Mandokoro was a governing institution that was part of the Kamakura bakufu.
Mandokoro was a governing institution that was part of the Kamakura bakufu.

sen.j: 前身は公文所である。
sen.e: Its former organization was Kumonjo (administration office).
It had been formerly known as the Kumonjo (administration office) organization.
It had been formerly known as the Kumonjo (administration office) organization.

sen.j: これは幕府を開いた源頼朝が上記のものと同じく従三位以上の公卿に許される政所開設の権利を獲得した
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Yoritomo who established the bakufu acquired the right to open Mandokoro, which until then had been only permitted to the court nobles ranked Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) or higher, and this had such a significance that his own governing system came to have an official character based on the 律令制Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).
sen.cmt: 源頼朝→MINAMOTO no Yoritomo 律令制→ the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code)
sen.e: This change was brought about by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo who opened up the bakufu to aquire the right to establish Mandokoro, which until then had only been open to court nobles ranked Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) or higher. This event had such significance that his own governing system took on a formal attribute based on the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).
sen.cmt: eliminated kanji, split the sentence in two; fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: This change was brought about by MINAMOTO no Yoritomo who opened up the bakufu to acquire the right to establish Mandokoro, which until then had only been open to court nobles ranked Jusanmi (Junior Third Rank) or higher.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: それにより、自らの統治機構が律令制に基づく公的性格を帯びる意義を持ったことによる。
sen.e: This event had such significance that his own governing system took on a formal attribute based on the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処

sen.j: 鎌倉幕府においては、一般政務・財政を司った。
sen.e: In Kamakura bakufu, it took charge of general political affaires and finance.
Mandokoro took charge of general political affairs and finance in the Kamakura bakufu.
sen.cmt: changed sentence order to read more smoothly
sen.e: Mandokoro took charge of general political affairs and finance in the Kamakura bakufu.

sen.j: 公文所から政所と改称された時期については様々な見解がある。
sen.e: There are various theories about the moment in which the name was changed from Kumonjo to Mandokoro.
There are various theories about the moment in which the name was changed from Kumonjo to Mandokoro.
There are various theories about the moment in which the name was changed from Kumonjo to Mandokoro.

sen.j: 1191年に公文所が政所と改称されたとされる説と、政所と改称されたのは1185年とする説がある（この年に源頼朝が三位以上（従二位）へ昇叙したことにより政所設置の資格を得たため）。
sen.e: There is a theory that the name was changed from Kumonjo to Mandokoro in 1191, and another insists that change of the name to Mandokoro took place in 1185 (because this year, MINAMOTO no Yoritomo was promoted to be ranked more than Sanmi (Third Rank) (Junii [Junior Second Rank]).
sen.cmt: 三位以上（従二位）Sanmi (Third Rank) (Junii [Junior Second Rank])
sen.e: There is a theory that the name was changed from Kumonjo to Mandokoro in 1191, and another insists that the name change occurred in 1185 (this theory is based on the fact that Yoritomo was promoted from Sanmi to Junii - Junior Second Rank during this year).

There is a theory that the name was changed from Kumonjo to Mandokoro in 1191, and another insists that the name change occurred in 1185 (this theory is based on the fact that MINAMOTO no Yoritomo was promoted from Sanmi to Junii - Junior Second Rank during this year).

sen.j: また、公文所と政所の連続性を否定して、大江広元が機能に重複する部分があった公文所と政所の別当を兼務した結果として公文所の機能が政所の機能に吸収されたとする説（「鎌倉市史」）もある。
sen.e: Also there is a theory that denies the continuity of Kumonjo and Mandokoro and argues that the function of Kumonjo was absorbed by that of Mandokoro in consequence of OE no Hiromoto's double posts in Kumonjo and Mandokoro as betto (director of a secretariat), both of which had some overlaps in function ("Kamakurashi-shi "(The History of Kamakura City).
sen.cmt: 大江広元→OE no Hiromoto 別当→betto (director of a secretariat) 「鎌倉市史」→"Kamakurashi-shi"(The History of Kamakura City).
sen.e: There is another theory that denies the continuity of Kumonjo and Mandokoro and argues that the functions of Kumonjo were absorbed by Mandokoro as a consequence of OE no Hiromoto being posted as betto (director of a secretariat) in both organizations where a number his work functions overlapped ("Kamakura-shi" - "The History of Kamakura City").
sen.cmt: double posts→being posted in both organizations; some→a number; fixed grammar to read more smoothly
sen.e: There is another theory that denies the continuity of Kumonjo and Mandokoro and argues that the functions of Kumonjo were absorbed by Mandokoro as a consequence of OE no Hiromoto being posted as betto (director of a secretariat) in both organizations where a number of his work functions overlapped ('Kamakura-shi' - 'The History of Kamakura City').

tit.cmt: 以下日本語の職名については、職内容の説明文章が続いて記載されている場合は日本語名をローマ字表記にしました。読み方は戦国武将職名[http://2member2.jcom.home.ne.jp/sengokubusyou/kamakurasyokumei.html][http://2member2.jcom.home.ne.jp/sengokubusyou/muromatisyokumei.html]を参照。なお、統一用語リストに掲載されていた訳語で採用しなかった語は、参考のために本欄に記載しました。

sen.j: 政所別当政所の長官。
sen.e: Mandokoro betto, director of Mandokoro (the Administrative Board)
sen.cmt: 政所別当→統一用語リストでは、Mandokoro betto (Director of the Administrative Board)です。
sen.e: Mandokoro betto (Director of the Mandokoro Administrative Board)
Mandokoro betto: Director of the Mandokoro Administrative Board

sen.j: 初代別当は大江広元。
sen.e: The first betto was OE no Hiromoto
The first betto was OE no Hiromoto
The first betto was OE no Hiromoto

sen.j: 後には執権または連署が兼任
sen.e: Later, the shikken (shogunal regent) or rensho (assistant to regents) doubled this duty.
Later on, the Shikken (shogunal regent) or Rensho (assistant to regents) would double as the betto.
sen.cmt: doubled this duty→would double as the betto
sen.e: Later on, the Shikken (shogunal regent) or Rensho (assistant to regents) would double as the betto.

sen.j: 令 政所の次官。
sen.e: Rei deputy director of Mandokoro
Rei - Deputy director of Mandokoro
Rei: Deputy director of Mandokoro

sen.j: 初代令は二階堂行政（後に広元ともに別当）。
sen.e: The first person who took the post of rei was Yukimasa NIKAIDO (later he and Hiromoto became the betto).
The first person to take the post of rei was Yukimasa NIKAIDO (later he and Hiromoto became the betto).
The first person to take the post of rei was Yukimasa NIKAIDO (later he and Hiromoto became the betto).

sen.j: 文書の署判役
sen.e: Shohanyaku (Inspector) of documents
sen.cmt: 署判役→定訳不明：Shohanyaku (Inspector) of documents。署判役の読みは[http://www.wul.waseda.ac.jp/古典籍総合データベース参照]
sen.e: Shohanyaku - (inspector) of documents
Shohanyaku: (inspector) of documents

sen.j: 政所執事政所の上級役人。
sen.e: Mandokoro shitsuji, senior official of Mandokoro
Mandokoro shitsuji - Senior official of Mandokoro
Mandokoro shitsuji: Senior official of Mandokoro

sen.j: 政務に参与し、会計を担当。
sen.e: He was committed in political affaires and took charge of accounting.
Involved with political affairs and took charge of accounting.
Involved with political affairs and took charge of accounting.

sen.j: 二階堂氏の世襲
sen.e: A descendant of the Nikaido clan
A descendant of the Nikaido clan

sen.j: 執事代 政所執事の代理官
sen.e: Shitsujidai, acting Mandokoro shitsuji
sen.cmt: 執事代→統一用語リストでは：deputy steward of the office of administrationです。
sen.e: Shitsujidai - Deputy steward of the office of administration
Shitsujidai: Deputy steward of the office of administration

sen.j: 案主 政所の下級役人。
sen.e: Anju, inferior official of Mandokoro
sen.cmt: 案主→統一用語リストでは：Anju (officer who recorded and stored documents at Shoens, authorities)です。
sen.e: Anju - Officer who recorded and stored documents at Shoens
Anju: Low-level official of Mandokoro

sen.j: 文案を作成する役
sen.e: An official to prepare drafts
An official to prepare drafts
An official to prepare drafts

sen.j: 知家事 政所の下級役人。
sen.e: Chikeji, Inferior official of Mandokoro
sen.cmt: 知家事→統一用語リストでは：Chikeji (an official working under mandokoro betto, or director of the administrative board)です。
sen.e: Chikeji - Official working under the Mandokoro betto or director of the administrative board
Chikeji: Low-level official of Mandokoro

sen.j: 文案を作成する役
sen.e: An official to prepare drafts
An official to prepare drafts
An official to prepare drafts

sen.j: 寄人 政所の雑用官。
sen.e: Yoryudo, a clerk in charge of miscellaneous general chose
sen.cmt: 寄人→統一用語リストでは：Yoryudo (dependent who served a verdict organ) [http://www.usc.edu/schools/college/history/kambun/2008/translations/Hyohanki_Hogen_2nen-e.pdf]です。
sen.e: Yoryudo - A clerk in charge of miscellaneous chores.
Yoryudo: A clerk in charge of miscellaneous chores.

sen.j: 当初、「政所公人」とも
sen.e: At first it was also called 'Mandokoro Kujin' (public clerk of Mandokoro)
sen.cmt: 「政所公人」→定訳不明：'Mandokoro Kujin' (public clerk of Mandokoro)としました。「公人」の読み方は[http://2member2.jcom.home.ne.jp/sengokubusyou/muromatisyokumei.html]を参照
sen.e: At first it was also called 'Mandokoro Kujin' (public clerk of Mandokoro)
At first it was also called 'Mandokoro Kujin' (public clerk of Mandokoro)

sen.j: 室町幕府の財政と領地に関する訴訟を掌る職。
sen.e: Post in charge of the financial administration and the lawsuits related to territory affaires in Muromachi bakufu.
Position in charge of the financial administration and lawsuits related to territory affairs in Muromachi bakufu.
Position in charge of the financial administration and lawsuits related to territory affairs in Muromachi bakufu.

sen.j: 執事は1379年以後、足利義政元服の時、二階堂忠行が一時執事となった他は、伊勢氏が世襲した。
sen.e: Shitsuji (chief of Mandokoro, the Administrative Board) became a hereditary post of the Ise clan since 1379, except for the moment to celebrate Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA's genpuku (coming of age), in which Tadayuki NIKAIDO took the post of shitsuji for a while.
sen.cmt: 執事→shitsuji (chief of Mandokoro, the Administrative Board) [http://homepage1.nifty.com/kitabatake/muromachijob.html#政所]
sen.e: Shitsuji (Chief of the Mandokoro, the Administrative Board) - became a hereditary post of the Ise clan after 1379, except for a short time to celebrate the genpuku (coming of age) of Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA where Tadayuki NIKAIDO filled the post.

Shitsuji (Chief of the Mandokoro, the Administrative Board) - became a hereditary post of the Ise clan after 1379, except for a short time to celebrate the genpuku (coming of age) of Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA where Tadayuki NIKAIDO filled the post.

sen.j: 政所執事 政所の長官。
sen.e: Mandokoro Shitsuji, chief of Mandokoro (the Administrative Board)
sen.cmt: 政所執事→統一用語リストでは：Mandokoro Shitsuji (chief of Mandokoro, the Administrative Board)です。
sen.e: Mandokoro Shitsuji (Chief of Mandokoro Shitsuji, the Administrative Board).
Mandokoro Shitsuji: Chief of Mandokoro, the Administrative Board).

sen.j: 佐々木氏、二階堂氏、京極氏らが任じられたが、後に伊勢氏が世襲
sen.e: The Sasaki clan, Nikaido clan and Kyogoku clan were appointed to the post, but later the Ise clan handed it down as a hereditary post.
The Sasaki clan, Nikaido clan and Kyogoku clan were appointed to the post, but later the Ise clan handed it down as a hereditary post.
The Sasaki clan, Nikaido clan and Kyogoku clan were appointed to the post, but later the Ise clan handed it down as a hereditary post.

sen.j: 政所執事代政所の次官。
sen.e: Mandokoro Shitsujidai, assistance administrator of Mandokoro
sen.cmt: 政所執事代→統一用語リストでは：deputy steward of the office of administrationです。
sen.e: Mandokoro Shitsujidai - Deputy Steward of the office of administration
sen.cmt: changed description to follow the word list described in the comment column
sen.e: Mandokoro Shitsujidai: Deputy Steward of the office of administration

sen.j: 斎藤氏、松田氏が交替で就任
sen.e: The Saito clan and the Matsuda clan took turns for the post.
The Saito clan and the Matsuda clan took turns for the post.
The Saito clan and the Matsuda clan took turns for the post.

sen.j: 政所代 執事の代理官。
sen.e: Mandokorodai, acting chief of Mandokoro
sen.cmt: 政所代→統一用語リストでは：proxy officer of Mandokoro (Administrative Board)です。
sen.e: Mandokorodai - Proxy Officer of Mandakoro Administrative Board
Mandokorodai: Proxy Officer of Mandokoro Administrative Board

sen.j: 伊勢氏の家臣の蜷川氏が世襲
sen.e: The Ninagawa clan, a vassal of the Ise clan took the charge as a hereditary post
The Ninagawa clan, a vassal of the Ise clan took the charge as a hereditary post
The Ninagawa clan, a vassal of the Ise clan took the charge as a hereditary post

sen.j: 寄人 政所の評定に参加する役人。
sen.e: Yoryudo, officer who took part in the 評定Council of State at Mandokoro
sen.cmt: 寄人→統一用語リストでは：yoriudo (a dependent, frequently on who served a noble house or proprietor)です。Council of State
sen.e: Yoriudo (a dependent who frequently served a noble house or proprietor) - Officer who took part in the Council of State at Mandokoro
Yoriudo (a dependent who frequently served a noble house or proprietor): Officer who took part in the Council of State at Mandokoro

sen.j: 公人 政所の雑用官。
sen.e: Kunin, a clerk in charge of miscellaneous general chose.
sen.cmt: 公人→読み方：（くにん）kunin [http://members2.jcom.home.ne.jp/sengokubusyou/muromatisyokumei.htm] なお、統一用語リストでは公人→Oyakebito です。
sen.e: Kunin - A clerk in charge of miscellaneous chores.
Kunin: A clerk in charge of miscellaneous chores.

sen.j: 「政所下部」とも
sen.e: It is also called '政所下部 Mandokoro Gebu' (low-ranked personnel at Mandokoro)
sen.cmt: 「政所下部」→ 定訳不明・読み方不明：'Mandokoro Gebu' (low-ranked personnel at Mandokoro)としました。
sen.e: Also known as 'Mandokoro Gebu' (low-ranked personnel at Mandokoro)
Also known as 'Mandokoro Gebu' (low-ranked personnel at Mandokoro)
